docs.title: Welcome
docs.text:
This small website lists my favourite recipes.

Most of these recipes require very little chopping or pot-watching. They're ideal for weeknights and busy lifestyles.

I've also included some that require a little more effort, but which are worth it!

docs.title: About this site
docs.text:
Hi, I'm Siobhan. I'm a technical writer, technical editor, and content strategist.

I'm using this content to familiarise myself with creating documentation via static site generators, as part of building out my tech stack.

In my previous roles as Senior Technical Writer and Chief Technical Editor, I used in-house docs-as-code tooling, and a bit of MadCap Flare. However, now that I'm self-employed, I'm getting up to speed on the many, many tools that can help manage documentation.

To learn more about my background, find me on LinkedIn: Siobhan Fitzgerald-Gibson.

docs.title: Extra effort meals
docs.text:
These recipes aren't as low-effort, but they are delicious, and they produce enough food to warrant making time to batch-cook them.

  • Sweet potato pasta sauce (Myriad Recipes), great with feta and pumpkin seeds (vg)
  • Cheesy leek & potato pie (BBC Good Food) with peas, veg and gravy (v)
  • One-pan roast chicken and potatoes (BBC Good Food) with peas, veg and gravy
    • You can then store the bones in the freezer until you have enough to make chicken stock for use in risottos.

docs.title: Lazy bowls
docs.text: Quick, easy rice bowls. Lazy versions of nice meals. These can be meat or veggie.

docs.title: Stir-fry bowl
docs.text:
Ingredients:

  • Protein: Any meat. If you have time, marinate in soy+vinegar/whatever else is around.
  • Vegetables: A stir-fry veg pack, or any leftover vegetables prepped for stir-frying.
  • Any rice
  • Optional extras: Kimchi, cashew nuts, sesame seeds, fried egg

Method:

  1. Put some rice on to cook (use the Instant Pot if available)
  2. Meanwhile, in a hot frying pan or wok, cook the protein until seared all over, then add the vegetables.
  3. Add any optional extras, if using.
  4. Ad rice to a bowl and serve the stir-fry over the top. Add a fried egg on top, if using.

docs.title: Bibimbap bowl
docs.text:
Ingredients:

  • Protein: Egg, chicken, whatever you have
  • Vegetables: Whatever vegetables you have, cooked as easily as possible.
  • Ssamjang
  • Short-grain rice

Method:

  1. Put some rice on to cook (use the Instant Pot if available)
  2. Cook or warm up some vegetables. For this, you can use any vegetables available. I like roasted root vegetables and steamed greens.
  3. Fry an egg. Optional: Sprinkle some sesame seeds into the pan as the egg is cooking.
  4. Make a bowl of rice, then top with the vegetables, a spoon of ssamjang, and the fried egg.

docs.title: Chilli bowl
docs.text:
Ingredients:

  • Frozen bean & chilli mix
  • Frozen mediterranean veg mix
  • Any spices you like (paprika is good!)
  • Chopped tomatoes
  • Optional: Any cooked meat

Method:

  1. In a hot saucepan, add the two frozen mixes, the spices, and the chopped tomatoes.
  2. Bring the pan to the boil, then simmer until everything is thawed and cooked through.
  3. Optional: Add the cooked meat and simmer until the mean is warmed through.
  4. Serve with rice, wraps, potatoes, or another carb of choice.

docs.title: Perfect roast potatoes
docs.text: For these three-way roasties, you boil, steam, and then roast your potatoes. This produces potatoes that are soft and fluffy on the inside, and extra crunchy on the outside.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• As many white potatoes as you want to roast
  • Salt
  • Pepper
  • Dried rosemary (Or your own selection of herbs / spices)

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Preheat the oven to 180-200C.
  2. Get a roasting tin. Pour in enough cooking oil to cover the bottom of the tin, then put the tin in the oven.
  3. Chop potatoes into whatever size you like your roast potatoes.
  4. Boil a pan of salted water, enough to cover all your potatoes (but don’t add the potatoes yet!).
  5. Whn the water starts boiling, add the chopped potatoes.
  6. Let the potatoes boil up and then simmer for around 5 minutes. It's okay if they're not fully cooked at this point.
  7. Use a colander to drain the potatoes.
  8. Pop a lid on top of the potatoes and let them steam in their own heat for around 5-10 mins (you can either put the potatoes back in the pan or leave them in the colander for this part).
  9. Take the roasting tin out of the oven (close the oven door to keep the heat in!), and pour the potatoes into the hot oil.
    • Important: Make sure the oil in the pan is already hot, as if you’re making Yorkshire puddings.
  10. Add generous amounts of salt, pepper, and dried rosemary or other herbs you like. Stir with a wooden spoon until all of the potatoes are coated in oil and seasoning.
  11. Put the potatoes in the oven and roast until starting to brown (this usually takes around 20-30 mins).
  12. Open the oven door and give the roast potatoes a good mix until all the potatoes are coated in oil again.
  13. Put the potatoes in the oven and roast until starting to brown (this usually takes another 20 mins, but judge it by eye).
  14. Take the potatoes out of the oven and admire them.

docs.title: Fried gnocchi with peas and pesto
docs.text:
Ingredients:

  • Gnocchi
  • Peas
  • Pesto
  • Side of steamed greens

Method:

  1. Boil the gnocchi until they float in the water.
  2. Heat a frying pan or wok with oil, and add the gnocchi.
  3. Meanwhile, heat some peas in the microwave, and steam some greens in the microwave.
  4. When the gnochhi is browned, add the peas and pesto to the pan to mox and warm through.
  5. Serve gnocchi with steamed greens on the side.

docs.title: Side: Steamed greens
docs.text:
Ingredients:

  • Any leafy greens

Method:

  1. Rinse the leave and chop them into strips.
  2. Put them in a microwaveable container with a very small splash of water (1tsp) and microwave for 1 minute.
  3. Before serving, add salt, pepper, and olive oil.
